DLV
Class TranslationMap

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--DLV.TranslationMap
public class TranslationMap
extends java.lang.Object

This class allows to specify how to convert a source "table" in a destination "table".
You can use a TranslationMap to map a table handled by a java.sql.ResultSet object in a predicate object and vice versa (see Tools.resultSetToPredicate(ResultSet, Predicate) and Tools.predicateToResultSet(Connection, String, Predicate, TranslationMap, boolean).
A TranslationMap is made of some TranslationMap.Couple objects. For each destination column index you set a couple creating a TranslationMap.Couple object. The following example will clarify what is a TranslationMap and how to use it.

Ex. TranslationMap

Suppose that you want to import a database table named "customers" in a Predicate object P.
If the "customers" table is as follows:

Name Birthdate Comments
John Leslie 21 Apr 1976 A customer
James Bond 10 Jan 1930 007
Roberto Baggio 25 Jul 1970 Football player
E.T. 01 jan 1000 Alien

and you want to obtain a Predicate object representing the following fact database:

customer("John Leslie", 1976-04-21, "A customer").
customer("James Bond", 1930-01-10, "007").
customer("Roberto Baggio", 1970-07-25, "Football player").
customer("E.T.", 1000-01-01, "Alien").

You must provide a way to map table columns to predicate arguments.

The required mapping can be obtained providing a TranslationMap.
We want to map:
- the first column whose type is CHAR in the first argument having QUOTED_STRING DLV Wrapper Type.
- the second column whose type is DATE in the second argument having DATE DLV Wrapper Type.
- the third column whose type is CHAR in the third argument having QUOTED_STRING DLV Wrapper Type.

The required TranslationMap can be represented as follows:

Destination index 1 2 3
Couples <1,QUOTED_STRING> <2,DATE> <3,QUOTED_STRING>

The following code implements this example in Java: 

            ...
        try
        {
            //create an SQL Statement from a java.sql.Connection object conn
            Statement st=conn.createStatement(
                                      ResultSet.TYPE_SCROLL_INSENSITIVE,
                                      ResultSet.CONCUR_UPDATABLE);
            //execute a selection query to import customers table
            ResultSet rs=st.executeQuery("select * from customers");

            //prepare an empty Predicate object named "customer" of arity 3
            Predicate p=new Predicate("customer",3);

            //encode the desired mapping by using a TranslationMap object
            TranslationMap map=new TranslationMap(p.arity());

            //To add a Couple to a map you just instantiate a new TranslationMap.Couple object.
            map.new Couple(1,1,ConversionType.QUOTED_STRING); //first customers column to the first predicate argument
            map.new Couple(2,2,ConversionType.DATE);          //second customers column to the second predicate argument
            map.new Couple(3,3,ConversionType.QUOTED_STRING); //third customers column to the third predicate argument

            //"transform" a java.sql.ResultSet in a Predicate object
            p=Tools.resultSetToPredicate(rs,p,map);
        ...
        }catch(Throwable t) { t.printStackTrace();}

Notice that you can also use a TranslationMap to "store" a Predicate object in a database table.
In the latter case you just remember that source and destination are swapped with respect to the first example.
The following Java code stores customers names and comments from the Predicate object customer in a table named customer_light. 

            ...
        try
        {
            //encode the desired mapping by using a TranslationMap object
            TranslationMap map=new TranslationMap(p.arity()-1);    //note that customer_light table has two colums.

            //To add a Couple to a map you just instantiate a new TranslationMap.Couple object.
            map.new Couple(1,1,ConversionType.QUOTED_STRING); //first predicate argument to the first customer_light column
            map.new Couple(3,2,ConversionType.QUOTED_STRING); //third predicate argument to the second customer_light column

            //"transform" a java.sql.ResultSet in a Predicate object
            Tools.predicateToResultSet(conn,"customer_light",p,map,false);
        ...
        }catch(Throwable t) { t.printStackTrace();}

You must also use a TranslationMap to define ResultSetHandler objects. A ResultSetHandler object allows to use a database table as input for DLV without "cache" facts in a Predicate object (see Program and ResultSetHandler).

Version:
1.0
Author:
Francesco Ricca
See Also:
ConversionType, Program, Predicate, ResultSetHandler, ConversionType

Constructor Detail

TranslationMap

public TranslationMap(int size)
Builds an empty TranslationMap of size "size".
If you build an empty map you must add Couples (see TranslationMap.Couple) by hand.

Parameters:
size - The size of the map.

TranslationMap

public TranslationMap(TranslationMap.Couple[] map)
Builds a TranslationMap from an array of Couples.

Parameters:
map - An array of Couples.

TranslationMap

public TranslationMap(PredicateMetaData pmd)
Builds a TranslationMap from a PredicateMetaData object.
The TranslationMap created has size equals to "pmd" arity; for each Couple, source index equals destination index and source type is given by the PredicateMetaData descriptor.

Parameters:
pmd - A PredicateMetaData object.
Method Detail

buildMetadata

public PredicateMetaData buildMetadata(java.lang.String[] columnNames)
Builds a PredicateMetaData object from a TranslationMap.
Column names must be specified in the "columnNames" argument, types are imported by the map.

Parameters:
columnNames - a String array which contains column names.
Returns:
A PredicateMetaData object compatible with this TranslationMap.

getSize

public int getSize()
Returns the size of this map (corresponds to predicate arity).

Returns:
The size of this map.
